Where Connectivity Issues Commonly Occur

Highlighting the Most Affected Areas and Target Regions for Improvement

Regions Most Affected

Connectivity challenges are most prevalent in rural and remote regions of Canada. The countryâ€™s vast geography and sparse populations in certain areas make it difficult to deploy and maintain modern internet infrastructure.

Some of the most affected regions include:

  • **Northern Canada**: Areas such as Nunavut, the Northwest Territories, and parts of Yukon.
  • **Rural Atlantic Canada**: Newfoundland and Labrador, and remote parts of New Brunswick and Nova Scotia.
  • **Prairie Provinces**: Farmland and rural communities in Manitoba and Saskatchewan.
  • **Remote British Columbia**: Mountainous regions and islands with limited connectivity.

Target Areas for Improvement

The federal government and private sectors have identified priority areas for broadband expansion and 5G deployment. These include:

  • Rural towns within **100 km of major cities**, to provide better access to underserved populations.
  • Key industries in remote regions, such as **mining operations in northern Ontario** and Alberta.
  • Indigenous communities that lack basic infrastructure for internet connectivity.
  • Tourist-heavy areas, such as **Prince Edward Island** and remote parts of the Rockies, where demand for connectivity is growing.
